Wouldn't you know it the one that crashes is Ken's??  Craziness.

There are=
 no dependencies other than the various files in the 
Resources directory a=
nd the .param file.  The directory where you're 
running PMAI.exe should co=
ntain the Resources directory (along with 
all its contents) and the AIPac.=
param file.  I've tested it on 
various machines and had no problems.  It i=
s all programmed in 
Win32, so a Windows machine should suffice.  Let me kn=
ow if you 
can't seem to work out what the issue is.

As for inputs and con=
trolling the application, I have uploaded an 
additional file to SourceForg=
e that explains some of the details.  
It is called ExtraDetails.txt, and I=
've copied the text of it 
below.  The application isn't very interesting i=
n its current state 
due to a long evolutionary step, but I give some ideas=
 on how to 
shorten that in the ExtraDetails.text file.  In particular, if =
you 
press the 'B' key, this will toggle the PacMan visualizer to show 
you=
 the best controller thus far.  Be patient after hitting the 'B' 
key, thou=
gh, as it doesn't realy show its effect until after an 
evolutionary step.
=

A lot of control can be gained from the AIPac.param file.  Also, 
there is=
 some brief explanation of the inputs used in that file.  As 
it stands, th=
e inputs are based on a window centered around PacMan 
which is 6 "tiles" i=
n radius.  This gives a 13x13 window around 
PacMan.  For each tile, there =
are inputs for each of the following:  
wall/no wall, dot/no dot, edible gh=
ost/no edible ghost, hunting 
ghost/no hunting ghost, powerup/no powerup.  =
This gives 13x13x5 
inputs - a lot, but it seems to work well.  You can con=
trol the 
window size in the AIPac.param file.

You can control the way the=
 inputs are determined using the AIType 
parameter.  It can be Global or Wi=
ndowed (described above).  If you 
set it to Global, the inputs are quite d=
ifferent and are 
controllable from the parameter file as well.  Here's a s=
nip from 
the parameter file with the inputs available in Global mode:



#=
Input Selection for Global AI type - 1=3Don 0=3Doff
#Number of inputs are c=
omputed from these - maximum of 34 when all 
are turned on	
#CheckForWalls =
gives 4 inputs, one for each direction around PacMan. 
The input is 1 if th=
ere is a wall there, 0 if PacMan can move that 
direction
#CheckDots gives =
4 inputs for each direction around PacMan, each 
with the total number of d=
ots on that side of PacMan's current 
position
#MaxDotDirection gives 4 inp=
uts, 1 of which will be set to 1 (others 
0) corresponding to the direction=
 in which most dots are present
GhostXY				1	
GhostState			1	
PowerUpXY			1=
	
PowerUpState			1    
PacManXY			1    
CheckForWalls			1    
CheckDots			0=

MaxDotDirection			1


I hope that helps to explain some of the details.  B=
e careful when 
adjusting the parameter file.  Spelling is important.  I us=
ed 
whitespace as the delimiter, so absolute positioning isn't 
important, =
but make sure you use spaces or tabs.  If you have any 
more questions, ple=
ase don't hesitate to ask.

-Kirk




AIPac Additional Details
10 April 200=
7
Robert Kirk DeLisle

Here are some additional details related to AIPac th=
at might come in 
useful.  I've tried to put the details in the order of in=
terest and 
those pieces that will get you up and running the fastest.

Rem=
ember that the Resource directory needs to be present.  This has 
all the g=
raphics, mazes, etc. needed for the simulator.  You can 
control most (all,=
 I think) of the details of where the various 
files are found within the p=
arameters files, AIPac.param, but I 
recommend leaving things as they are u=
ntil you're familiar with the 
program.

While the simulator is running, if=
 you press the 'B' key, this will 
toggle displaying the current best PacMa=
n controller after each 
generation.  Remember that there will be a delay i=
n displaying the 
best controller due to the fact that generations take a w=
hile to 
process.

Currently, I have the parameters set up for a rather len=
gthy 
evolution step.  If you want to see some action more quickly, try 
ch=
anging the following parameters in AIPac.param:

Replicates	- In the availa=
ble downloads, I have this set to 10 
which means that each PacMan controll=
er will be tested 10 times and 
a measure of performance assessed across th=
e multiples.  Set this to 
a smaller number and things will run faster.

Po=
pSize 	- Obviously, reducing population size will make 
things faster, alth=
ough potentially less interesting.

AIType		- I have this set to Windowed w=
hich defines a window 
around PacMan, as described in the readme file.  Set=
ting this to 
Global will be a very different type of AI.  Specifically, th=
e 
inputs defined in the section following AIType setting will be used 
rat=
her than a window around PacMan.  This will shrink the number of 
inputs si=
gnificantly, but I've found it to be less interesting.



If there are othe=
r questions or comments, please leave a message in 
the forum.
